Posts.Content: if you want the best expertise in MRI guided biopsy in this country investigate Dr.Joe Bush in Chattanoga, TN, this is the most dedicated doctor with the best expertise, hands down, or get mp3TMRI in bore (not fusion) somwhere else and get him to review your MRI images and refor $200 fee
Posts.Title: Biopsy questions???

Posts.Content: I recently had mp3TMRI and report found one lesion described and located as follows: " in the 7 o'clock location of right peripheral zone on image 10 is a 5 mm nodule..... This is suggestive of a small volume of low to intermediate grade prostate cancer" further down in the report under Impresion: " Small indeterminate finding measuring 4X5 mm in the posterolateral right peripheral zone at the mid gland described above..... This either represents a small component of low to intermediate grade cancer versus inflammatory response" So, I got a second opinion from two well known prostate MRI radiology experts confirming the above. Subsequently my uro knowing my MRI results referred me for a targeted biopsy, being a standard 12 core plus two additional cores in targeted areas as identified on MRI. MRI guided biopsy not available in my area. Today I just got pathology report as follows: Carcinoma Summary: Gleason score:3+3=6 found in right base lat, 15% of one core involved High grade PIN: identified in 4 cores out of 14 Extend of cancer on biopsies: 1/14 cores, approximately 1% of total core tissue. Targeted area on biopsy report was: Right apex TZ(transitional zone) So here is why I am confused, why biopsy radiologist targeted different area from one identified in MRI, MRI clearly identified "right peripheral zone" and biopsy targeted Right apex TZ(transitional zone) those are two different areas right?, am I correct?? And why area identified by biopsy with G6 was not found by 3 prostate expert radiologists reviewing my MRI, how it's possible?? now I wonder if I still have this MRI found lesion still lurking and growing?? but not found on biopsy need some explanation, please, before I see my urologist, thanks I am 68 years, live in Canada PSA 7.2 raising over the last 2-3 years from ~4.0 freePSA 18.2 PCA3 26 DRE negative
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with questions

Posts.Content: my original biopsy pathology was confirmed by Dr.Epsten, looking now at Focal Laser Ablasion by Dr.Walser, UTMB, Tx, or AS

Posts.Title: Biopsy questions???

Posts.Content: Hello, I am 67 old with PSA slowly growing to currently at 6, recent test shows PCA3=26, %PSA free 23.3%, PSA free1.14, PSA total 4.9 I am not rushing for a biopsy and my urologist, very experienced one, is OK with this and I intend to have 3T MRI done (before possible biopsy) at Rolling Oaks Radiology, in Thousands Oaks, CA, under direction of Dr. Princenthal, anyone with any experience with this facility or this radiologist? Any comments will be apreciated, thanks, Andrew
Posts.Title: Prostate 3T MRI exam

Posts.Content: Thanks for your comments, as to my PSA, most recent september tests show 6.1 and 6.0, in previous years, in 2013 was 4.1, in 2014 was 4.6 and this spring was 5.0 and 5.2 In October I took a test for a Free PSA with results as below: %PSA free 23.3%, PSA free1.14, PSA total 4.9 I am a canadian and will be paying for this 3TMRI on my own ($895), as this is not avaiable in Canada, PCA3 is avaiable but not covered and I paid $385 CAD
Posts.Title: Prostate 3T MRI exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH You're right about that. Nobody wants to go through one biopsy after another. The average 12-core "blind" biopsy misses tumors about 20% of the time. However, you might consider what is known as a "saturation biopsy." In this single procedure, they take more than the standard 12 cores. At least 20 and as many as 40+ can be taken. Often the patient is put to sleep in this version of the procedure. The thing to remember is that you will never get any official PC diagnosis with the MRI. An MRI simply cannot render such a diagnosis. The only procedure that can literally detect and diagnose prostate cancer is a biopsy. So, if you want the best chance of detecting any prostate cancer that might be present, the saturation way might be best. On the other hand, if you have the 3T MRI, it could then be followed up by a standard 12-core biopsy that tries to focus on areas "suggested" by the MRI. No fun no matter what you do, but a biopsy is probably going to have to be performed at some point in the future. agree, one problem might be, saturation biopsy might not be a preferred way for most urologist in Canada, might not be even available, since we have subsidized health care system we are not as progressive and some procedures are still not widely accepted or approved and covered

Posts.Content: I am retired and already snowbirding in Arizona right now, I don't have "lots of money" but spending $895 is definitely worth to me and I can afford it to spend this on my care, single biopsy also can often tell nothing, and taking multiple biopsy is no fun
